    Getting Started Customising cards

Customising cards

Source: vignettes/articles/custom-cards.Rmd
custom-cards.Rmd
library(bs4cards)

The bs4cards package comes with a data set galleries:

galleries
#>                long_name   short_name       date
#> 1    Ash Cloud and Blood          ash 2021-07-17
#> 2 Ghosts on Marble Paper       ghosts 2021-01-09
#> 3              Ice Floes    ice-floes 2021-01-19
#> 4           Native Flora native-flora 2021-02-10
#> 5            Silhouettes  silhouettes 2021-01-24
#> 6            Track Marks  track-marks 2020-09-20
#> 7              Viewports    viewports 2021-02-28
#>                                                                             blurb
#> 1          Simulated watercolours in ggplot2 using the transparent polygon method
#> 2                                     Abstract landscapes generated using ambient
#> 3                                       Abstract icebergs generated using ambient
#> 4                  Collections of small flametrees that resemble branching plants
#> 5                       Trees generated in flametree with random walk backgrounds
#> 6 Voronoi tessellations with seed points sampled from an iterated function system
#> 7                       Simple masks with ggfx using flametree-generated textures
#>             paintbrushes
#> 1                ggplot2
#> 2                ambient
#> 3                ambient
#> 4      ggplot2 flametree
#> 5 ggplot2 rcpp flametree
#> 6           ggplot2 rcpp
#> 7      ggplot2 flametree

Define some convenience functions that specify URLs for the image thumbnail and the target location for a link:

locate_thumbnail <- function(x) {
  paste0("https://bs4cards.djnavarro.net/image/", x, ".jpg")
} 
locate_gallery <- function(x) {
  paste0("https://art.djnavarro.net/gallery/", x)
}

Off we go:

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    text = date,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name)
  )
Ash Cloud and Blood

2021-07-17

Ghosts on Marble Paper

2021-01-09

Ice Floes

2021-01-19

Native Flora

2021-02-10

Silhouettes

Viewports

2021-02-28

Choosing a layout

Vertical layouts

The bs4cards package supports six different layouts: two “vertical” layouts, two “horizontal” layouts, and two “inset” layouts. If you want vertically oriented cards, set layout = "label-above" or layout = "label-below" (the default) to create the cards:

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    footer = paste("posted on", date),
    width = "wide",
    layout = "label-above"
  )
Ash Cloud and Blood
posted on 2021-07-17
Ghosts on Marble Paper
posted on 2021-01-09
Ice Floes
posted on 2021-01-19
Native Flora
posted on 2021-02-10
Silhouettes
posted on 2021-01-24
Track Marks
posted on 2020-09-20
Viewports
posted on 2021-02-28
galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    text = blurb,
    footer = paste("posted on", date),
    width = "wide",
    layout = "label-below"
  )

Horizontal layouts

To set horizontal layouts, set layout = "label-left" or layout = "label-right":

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    text = blurb,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    width = "very-wide",
    layout = "label-left"
  )
Ash Cloud and Blood

Simulated watercolours in ggplot2 using the transparent polygon method

Ghosts on Marble Paper

Abstract landscapes generated using ambient

Ice Floes

Abstract icebergs generated using ambient

Native Flora

Collections of small flametrees that resemble branching plants

Silhouettes

Trees generated in flametree with random walk backgrounds

Track Marks

Voronoi tessellations with seed points sampled from an iterated function system

Viewports

Simple masks with ggfx using flametree-generated textures

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    text = blurb,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    width = "very-wide",
    footer = paste("posted on", date),
    layout = "label-right",
    breakpoint = 7/12
  )

Inset layouts

The inset layouts place the “label” part of the card as a floating overlay on top of the image. The overlay can appear at the top or the bottom, depending on whether layout = "inset-top" or layout = "inset-bottom":

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    width = "wide",
    layout = "inset-top", 
    colour = "#ffffffcc"
  )
Ash Cloud and Blood
Ghosts on Marble Paper
Ice Floes
Native Flora
Silhouettes
Track Marks
Viewports
 
galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    width = "wide",
    layout = "inset-bottom", 
    colour = "#ffffffcc", 
    rounding = 0
  )

    width = "wide",
    layout = "inset-bottom", 
    colour = "#ffffffcc"
  )

  )

2021-02-28

Tags

The tags argument can be used to assign each card to a set of tags, and adds toggle buttons at the top of the card list that the user can do to display only those cards possessing the tag in question. The tags should be a single string, with spaces separating each tag. In the galleries data, the paintbrushes variable contains a list of some of the packages that were used in generating each generative art system. It’s generally a good idea to have one tag that is possessed by all of the cards. The bs4cards package doesn’t enforce this, but it’s easy to do as illustrated below:

galleries %>% 
  cards(
    title = long_name,
    text = blurb,
    link = locate_gallery(short_name),
    image = locate_thumbnail(short_name),
    tags = paste("all", paintbrushes),
    width = "very-wide",
    footer = paintbrushes,
    layout = "label-right",
    breakpoint = 7/12
  )

Ash Cloud and Blood

Simulated watercolours in ggplot2 using the transparent polygon method

ggplot2
Ghosts on Marble Paper

Abstract landscapes generated using ambient

ambient
Ice Floes
